SO...forum software with instant updates sans page refreshes?
hi everyone

Calling it forum software doesn't really seem accurate either as it's not geared for the longer, formatted posts that forums would allow. The best description is that it's Convore, but if you need an analogy I'd say it's more like Facebook status updates (non-formatted, typically short but not constrained by length, can include URLs, pictures) brought together by groups and topics.

yes I spent way too long setting up that joke

@tomdiggity I'll agree with you on that.  Furthermore, I saw some updates come through with the little red number markers and decided this is awesome.  I know everyone will make this comparison, but it's like twitter; except we might actually have the opportunity to say something meaningful or even profound.

@reallythecrash I concur. Look to the left at Recent Topics and the Groups in the nav bar. Those little red numbers are genius. The interface is so well thought out.  Twitter can be more of a broadcast mechanism, a playground for narcissists and public way of sharing bookmarks.  This has great potential to be engaging.

@tomdiggity Yes, I love the interface.  Twitter should just go bury itself in a desert somewhere, imo.  Using twitter is like playing charades with a snake, or scrabble without any vowels.  (I don't know why I'm using family game references.)
@reallythecrash nice analysis

This is kinda nice, it's like the best bits of a forum (topics, threads) with the best bits of twitter/facebook (no signatures, smaller updates) and yet it somehow manages to lose most of the downsides of both.

the user interface is really well thought out and technology wise, the comet push for live updates are implemented seamlessly into the user interface. but as an idea, I don't think it's much different from FB Groups, Yahoo Groups, Google Groups or as this topc title says, "fancy implementation of a forum".

yes i think this is JUST a afncy implementation of a forum, but hell it was time ! bulletin board and irc were loosing ground in front of facebook and twitter. But for me twitter and facebook is not about conversation, it's about exposing yourself. People just loose the sense of what a conversation is. So you have to make it fancy for people to give it a try again. I'm really interested in the future of convore since i'm doing the same thing in France.

@misofr I completely agree. I think a lot of people are giving up on forums, IRC, etc. in favor of things like Twitter and Facebook. I'm a big Twitter user, but it definitely has a different purpose than something like IRC. I see Convore as kind of a mash-up that could draw more people back to a conversation-focused medium.

interface is great !! ..but still don't get it's near perfect use when I can still be on IRC for my group discussion.
I like this.

I think the website is not the core of what the convore team wants. The API is the core, with it you can build your own website with your own look and feel, you can build widget to embed in websites (Disqus anyone ?) , you can build your mobile native client, you can even build bots.

It's more of a facebook group but public, and the posts and chat sections are merged. When posting it feels like a forum but when replying it feels like a chat.
Also, it tells me I submitted that 3 minutes ago even though I JUST submitted. Weird!
I don't know.. seems pretty much like a fancy forum.

@YogeshMali The power is being able to switch context across many different topics of interest in one tool/destination.  It's what's common across all these platforms, " Go big or go home"  It's why Convore for Cats would be a big waste of time.  Now the question is what do things look like when you have the masses in this system?  Does the UI even scale to keep track of the conversation flow.
why not

For me it's not facebook groups or something like that. going back to the roots, it's rather usenet meets irc in the age of Web 2.0. It has nice UX but still lacks little bit of basic components (think features) of both usenet and irc for the reasons those were designed.
/me wonders if usability matters for IRC
It's like IRC but with forum taxonomy. I think that's a miss. Topics are the concept that can be the most improved in BOTH of those examples.

IMO The key to getting the masses involved is public groups with easy URLs like http://convore.com/apple this makes it easy to share/remember/anticipate a group name. The next step once the masses are there is to have a lot of moderators (in addition to a few admins) to keep an eye on things. The same way flickr groups are policed by whoever created the group and those that were promoted from members to moderators. In order for this to work there needs to be a rule that short easy group names need to be used for public groups. 

It seems like to me you then have a scalable and useful tool.
@craigshipp Do you think a lot of people will actually be typing in the URL to go to groups rather than just logging in and selecting it from their group list?

@JohnFail If the URLs are public groups then yes for example if I wanted to chat about Nikon I would try http://convore.com/nikon and see what's there. Also, if I want to share a group it's easy to e-mail/tweet/facebook a simple URL and once seen others can easily remember. IMO it just makes it easier to brand a public group if it has a simple and representative URL. This is another reason the iPhone app should allow find by URL as an option in the group search.
@craigshipp Ah, I see now. You're referring more to when you are looking for a group that you aren't following yet. That would be pretty handy.
i just jumped into the convore pool. Sez here that 15 members are online now, but latest entry is a month ago?
@quickdrawartist yep, not much uptake so far. A shame because convore has a lot of potential. I just hope the founders have enough runway to get this thing off the ground!
@craigshipp it looks like it's already going dead?
I dont want this to die :(
yeah, this thing is great.. I personally like it more than Quora
Cool
It seems to be already dying
whats this ?

Quora and Convore are different things. Still this place is far from real-time as promised. I miss quality of IRC in 90ties on the right channels and with right people. Convore reminds me that little bit, but has much weaker experience in that experience of real-time communication.
@hollowone that's just because there are not enough users....give it time and spread the word and help the service grow. Please.

@craigshipp, I'm evangelising Convore among my communities, trust me. Still 12-13 active members as I see right now ten years ago, on right irc channel would generate vivid talk consuming hours of your time and attention. I have one problem with Convore - it's perfect for reactive usage and weak for proactive. By reactive I mean reading logs of lets say "conversations". Proactive means having a conversation. Chat means I write something and I get answer within 10-15 seconds. Waiting more ends a conversation, at least if you define it as real-time. Current formulat of Convore would end in spam if we had here 2000 active users instead of 12, I'm affraid.
@equinox it was fun for awhile but I went back to irc and really just it on my phone but it is a strong platform and maybe with a little open source TLC could be an amazing software package
@equinox We're still really small, just a three-person team right now.  Sometime in the future we'll be hiring, but not quite yet.

@hollowone According to @Leah it's still being worked on. She wants to rework some of convore, and is expecting to have a new version out by the end of summer. You can check the feedback subforum for the comments from her.
This topic in particular: https://convore.com/feedback/whats-cooking-at-convore/
